block.p: Computer Virus Is Traced To Apartment in Philippines More than a dozen law enforcement agents raided a Manila apartment from which they said a malicious computer program was unleashed last week, disrupting computer systems around the world. They took one resident into custody and ordered his roommate, a woman, to turn herself in.

The agents, including two representing the Federal Bureau of Investigation, apparently expected to find the computer from which the attack was started. A local official said that no computer was found, but that a box containing 17 items including telephones, wires, computer disks and computer magazines was seized. The officials would not say what had led them to the apartment and did not characterize the moves as arrests. [Page A1.]

Computer Virus Is Traced To Apartment in Philippines More than a dozen law enforcement agents raided a Manila apartment from which they said a malicious computer program was unleashed last week, disrupting computer systems around the world. They took one resident into custody and ordered his roommate, a woman, to turn herself in.

The agents, including two representing the Federal Bureau of Investigation, apparently expected to find the computer from which the attack was started. A local official said that no computer was found, but that a box containing 17 items including telephones, wires, computer disks and computer magazines was seized. The officials would not say what had led them to the apartment and did not characterize the moves as arrests. [Page A1.]

Boeing Names Top Financial Officer Boeing named Michael Sears as its chief financial officer, replacing Deborah C. Hopkins, who left after only 16 months for the same position at Lucent Technologies. Mr. Sears, 52, has been president of Boeing's military aircraft and missile systems unit. He came to Boeing from McDonnell Douglas. [C16.]

Nasdaq Falls, but Dow Up 25 Points Technology stocks sank after a bearish report on Cisco Systems rekindled doubts on the value of technology shares. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 147.44 points, or 3.9 percent, to 3,669.38. The Dow Jones industrial average increased 25.77 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,603.63, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index decreased 8.46 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,424.17. [C16.]

Painting on Ebay Creates a Frenzy Bidding on eBay for a painting that may or may not be by a well-known artist soared from a quarter to $135,805. The six-figure sale is one of the highest prices paid online for art, and serves as powerful testimony to the ability of the Internet to ignite a sales frenzy. [A1.]

Federal Judge Rules Against Napster A federal judge has decided not to dismiss a lawsuit filed by the recording industry against Napster, which offers a service that allows consumers to share and trade music over the Internet. The judge also suggested that Napster might face an uphill battle as the case proceeded to trial. [C8.]

First Analysis of Genome Project The biotechnology company DoubleTwist said it had identified as many as 105,000 human genes by performing the first comprehensive computer analysis of the publicly available data from the Human Genome Project. [C2.]

NTT Communications to Buy Verio NTT Communications of Japan agreed to buy Verio, a Web site manager, for $5.5 billion in cash. The move is part of an aggressive new strategy by the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone unit to expand globally. NTT Communications currently holds a 10 percent stake in Verio. Shares of Verio jumped 62 percent, up $22.375, to $58.3125. [C4.]

BellSouth to Add Digital Offerings BellSouth intends to announce today that it has signed a long-term contract to purchase satellite services from General Electric so that it can offer digital television service throughout the Southeast. [C6.]
Stanford to Offer Medical Data Stanford University is establishing a company to provide medical information online to doctors, while they meet with patients. [C4.]

Mexican Bank Is Sold at Auction The Spanish bank Banco Santander Central Hispano won a government auction for Mexico's oldest and third-largest bank, Grupo Financiero Serfin, trumping a rival bid from the British-based HSBC Holdings. [C4.]

G.M. Hires Star Renault Designer General Motors has hired Anne Asensio, 37, a star designer who helped transform Renault from an also-ran in the European auto industry into one of the industry's most feared competitors. [C2.]
